title: 51 Top React JS Basic Interview Questions for Beginners (2026)
description: Start from zero. Over 50 basic React JS interview questions covering the most important concepts for beginners, from JSX to the component lifecycle.

sections.title: Introduction: Laying the Foundation
sections.content: Every expert was once a beginner. To master React, you must first understand its basic building blocks. This guide provides over 50 essential questions to help you build a rock-solid foundation in **React JS**.

sections.title: 1. What is React? (Q1-Q10)
sections.content:
**Q1: Who developed React?**
React was developed by Jordan Walke, a software engineer at Meta (Facebook).

**Q2: When was React released?**
It was first deployed on Facebook's News Feed in 2011 and open-sourced in 2013.

**Q3: What is the main goal of React?**
To provide high speed, simplicity, and scalability in building user interfaces.

**Q4: Is React a programming language?**
No, it's a JavaScript library.

**Q5: What is the 'declarative' nature of React?**
You describe *what* the UI should look like for various states, and React updates the DOM to match it.

**Q6: What is a Single Page Application (SPA)?**
An application that loads a single HTML page and dynamically updates it as the user interacts with the app.

**Q7: How does React fit into the MVC architecture?**
React is primarily the 'V' (View) in Model-View-Controller.

**Q8: What is 'Learn Once, Write Anywhere'?**
A React philosophy meaning you can use the same concepts for web (React), mobile (React Native), and VR.

**Q9: What is the NPM package for React?**
The two main packages are `react` and `react-dom`.

**Q10: What is the current version of React?**
As of 2026, React 19 is the latest stable release (v-next might be out depending on the exact date).

sections.title: 2. JSX & Elements (Q11-Q20)
sections.content:
**Q11: What is JSX syntax?**
A syntax extension that looks like HTML but is actually JavaScript.

**Q12: Why do we use JSX?**
It makes writing component templates easier and more readable.

**Q13: Is JSX mandatory?**
No, but it's highly recommended. You can use `React.createElement` instead.

**Q14: What is a React Element?**
The smallest building block of React. It's a plain object describing what you want to see on the screen.

**Q15: Difference between Element and Component?**
A component is a function/class that returns elements. An element is what the component produces.

**Q16: How do you embed expressions in JSX?**
By wrapping the JavaScript expression in curly braces `{}`.

**Q17: Why use className instead of class?**
`class` is a reserved keyword in JavaScript.

**Q18: Why use htmlFor instead of for?**
`for` is a reserved keyword in JavaScript (used in loops).

**Q19: Can you write comments in JSX?**
Yes, using `/* comment */` inside curly braces.

**Q20: What is 'Transpilation' in React?**
Converting JSX/Modern JS into older JS that browsers can understand, usually done by Babel.

sections.title: 3. Components & Data (Q21-Q30)
sections.content:
**Q21: What are functional components?**
JavaScript functions that take props and return React elements.

**Q22: What are class components?**
ES6 classes that extend `React.Component` and have a `render()` method.

**Q23: When to use functional components?**
Almost always. Modern React development focuses exclusively on functions with Hooks.

**Q24: What are props?**
Inputs to a component passed by the parent.

**Q25: What is state?**
An object that holds mutable data specific to a component.

**Q26: Can props change?**
No, they are read-only (immutable).

**Q27: How to change state?**
Using `setState()` in classes or the hook updater in functional components.

**Q28: What is component composition?**
Building complex components by combining simpler ones.

**Q29: What is 'Props Drilling'?**
Passing data deeply through many component layers.

**Q30: What is a Parent component?**
A component that contains other components (Children) in its JSX.

sections.title: 4. Rendering & Lists (Q31-Q40)
sections.content:
**Q31: How to render a list of items?**
Using the JavaScript `map()` method.

**Q32: Why are keys important in lists?**
They help React identify which items have changed or moved for efficient updates.

**Q33: Can you use Math.random() as a key?**
No, keys must be stable across renders. Random keys will cause components to unmount/remount every time.

**Q34: What is conditional rendering?**
Displaying elements only if certain conditions are met.

**Q35: What is the tertiary operator?**
`condition ? true : false`. Used for simple if-else in JSX.

**Q36: What is the logical && operator?**
`condition && <Element />`. Used to render something only if a condition is true.

**Q37: What is 'null' rendering?**
Returning `null` from a component to prevent it from displaying anything.

**Q38: What is the root DOM node?**
The HTML element (usually `<div id="root">`) where the entire React app is mounted.

**Q39: What is React.Fragment?**
A component that groups children without adding a wrapper div to the DOM.

**Q40: What is the shorthand for React.Fragment?**
Empty tags: `<> ... </>`.

sections.title: 5. Events & Style (Q41-Q50)
sections.content:
**Q41: How do you name events in React?**
Using camelCase, like `onClick` or `onKeyDown`.

**Q42: How to prevent default event behavior?**
By explicitly calling `e.preventDefault()`.

**Q43: What is a Synthetic Event?**
React's cross-browser wrapper around the browser's native event.

**Q44: How to apply inline styles?**
Using an object with camelCase properties: `<div style={{ color: 'red' }}>`.

**Q45: What are CSS Modules?**
A way to scope CSS locally to a component automatically.

**Q46: What is 'props.children'?**
A special prop that represents whatever is nested inside the component tags.

**Q47: Can you have multiple components in one file?**
Yes, but it's best practice to keep one major component per file.

**Q48: What is 'Export Default'?**
Exporting one main thing from a file.

**Q49: What is 'Named Export'?**
Exporting multiple things from a file using their names.

**Q50: What is a Ref?**
A way to access the underlying DOM node directly when needed.

**Q51: Is React only for the web?**
No, React Native allows building mobile apps for iOS and Android.

sections.title: Summary
sections.content: These **51 basic questions** cover the essential vocabulary of a React developer. Understanding these is the first step toward becoming a professional engineer.
